abstractText: Suitable discretizations through tensor product formulas of popular multidimensional operators (diffusion– advection, for instance) lead to matrices with d-dimensional Kronecker sum structure. For evolutionary PDEs containing such operators and integrated in time with exponential integrators, it is of paramount importance to efficiently approximate actions of φ-functions of this kind of matrices. In this work, we show how to produce directional split approximations of third order with respect to the time step size. They conveniently employ tensor-matrix products (realized with highly performance level 3 BLAS) and that allow for the effective usage in practice of exponential integrators up to order three. The approach has been successfully tested against state-of-the-art techniques on two well-known physical models, namely FitzHugh–Nagumo and Schnakenberg.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
We are interested in the solution of stiff systems of Ordinary Differential Equations (ODEs) of type
u′(t) = Ku(t) + g(t,u(t)) = F (t,u(t)), u(0) = u0, (1a)
by means of exponential integrators [1]. The stiff part is represented by the matrix K ∈ CN×N which we assume to have d-dimensional Kronecker sum structure
K = Ad ⊕Ad−1 ⊕ · · · ⊕A1 = d ∑
µ=1
A⊗µ, A⊗µ = Id ⊗ · · · ⊗ Iµ+1 ⊗Aµ ⊗ Iµ−1 ⊗ · · · ⊗ I1. (1b)
Here, Aµ ∈ Cnµ×nµ and Iµ is the identity matrix of size nµ. Moreover, g(t,u(t)) is a nonlinear function of t and of the unknown u(t) ∈ CN , with N = n1 · · ·nd. Throughout the paper the symbol ⊗ denotes the Kronecker product of matrices, while ⊕ is employed for the Kronecker sum of matrices. Systems in form (1) naturally arise when discretizing in space some Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) defined on tensor product domains and with appropriate boundary conditions. In those cases, Aµ are matrices which correspond to differential or fractional one-dimensional operators after discretization with (nonuniform) finite differences, tensor product finite or spectral elements, and usually encapsulate boundary conditions. Typical examples are (systems of) evolutionary PDEs which contain diffusion–advection operators, among the others.
In References [2, 3] it is shown that the well-known exponential Runge–Kutta method of order two etd2rk
un2 = un + τϕ1(τK)F (tn,un), un+1 = un2 + τϕ2(τK)(g(tn+1,un2)− g(tn,un)), (2)
where τ is the time step size, if directionally split outperforms other well-established methods in the solution of stiff advection–diffusion–reaction models. The appearing ϕ-functions are exponential-like matrix functions and, for generic X ∈ CN×N , have Taylor expansion
ϕℓ(X) = ∞ ∑
k=0
Xk
(k + ℓ)! , ℓ ≥ 0.
The key points to develop of the directional split integrator based on method (2) were the observation that
ϕ1(τK) = ϕ1(τAd)⊗ · · · ⊗ ϕ1(τA1) +O(τ2), ϕ2(τK) = 2d−1ϕ2(τAd)⊗ · · · ⊗ ϕ2(τA1) +O(τ2), (3)
∗Corresponding author Email addresses: marco.caliari@univr.it (Marco Caliari), fabio.cassini@univr.it (Fabio Cassini)
and that the actions of the right hand sides can be efficiently realized in tensor form with Tucker operators (see also References [4, 5] for insights on the relevant tensor-matrix operations). However, the second order accuracy of the formula with respect to the time step size limits its applicability to schemes of at most order two.
In this paper we aim at introducing directional split approximations of third order with respect to τ for exponential-like ϕ-functions of matrices with d-dimensional Kronecker sum structure. The formulas derived in the subsequent section allow for an efficient construction and employment of exponential integrators of order three for ODEs systems with Kronecker sum structure, as shown with the accompanying numerical experiments.

sections.heading: 2. Third order directional splitting
sections.text:
We focus here on three-stage exponential Runge–Kutta integrators of the form
un2 = un + c2τϕ1(c2τK)F (tn,un), un3 = un + c3τϕ1(c3τK)F (tn,un) + τa32(τK)dn2,
un+1 = un + τϕ1(τK)F (tn,un) + τ(b2(τK)dn2 + b3(τK)dn3), (4a)
where dni = g(tn + ciτ,uni)− g(tn,un), i = 2, 3. (4b)
From Reference [6, Section 5.2], we know that we can construct integrators of stiff order three in which the coefficients aij(τK) and bi(τK) involve just the ϕ1 and ϕ2 functions. Therefore, we will fully develop our approximation techniques using these two functions only.
The starting point for the realization of efficient direction split exponential integrators is the following formula for the matrix exponential of the Kronecker sum K = A⊗1 + · · ·+A⊗d [4, 5]
exp(τK)v = exp(τA⊗1) · · · exp(τA⊗d)v = (exp(τAd)⊗ · · · ⊗ exp(τA1))v = vec(V ×1 exp(τA1)×2 · · · ×d exp(τAd)).
(5)
Here V is an order-d tensor such that vec(V ) = v and ×µ denotes the µ-mode product, i.e., a tensor-matrix product along the direction µ. The concatenation of µ-mode products is usually referred to as Tucker operator. The advantage of this formulation is that it allows to compute the action of the matrix exponential of K through a single Tucker operator (that, in fact, constitutes the main part of the computational cost) without assembling the matrix itself, and relying on high performance level-3 BLAS operations after the computation of the small sized matrix exponentials exp(τAµ) (which has negligible computational cost). The employment of time integrators that rely on such matrix/tensor formulations have received a great attention in the latest years (see, for instance, References [7–11]). Concerning the functions ϕℓ with ℓ > 0, which are needed for the exponential integrators considered in this work, we notice that the first equality in formula (5) is not valid anymore. However, in Reference [2] it is shown that
ϕℓ(τK)v = ℓ! d−1ϕℓ(τA⊗1) · · ·ϕℓ(τA⊗d)v +O(τ2)
= ℓ!d−1 (ϕℓ(τAd)⊗ · · · ⊗ ϕℓ(τA1))v +O(τ2) = vec ( ℓ!d−1V ×1 ϕℓ(τA1)×2 · · · ×d ϕℓ(τAd) ) +O(τ2), (6)
of which expressions (3) are particular cases. Notice that in the case d = 2 the formula simply reduces to
ϕℓ(τ(A⊗1 +A⊗2))v = vec ( ϕℓ(τA1)(ℓ!V )ϕℓ(τA2) T ) +O(τ2), (7)
since for 2-way tensors (i.e., matrices) 1- and 2- mode products are just the standard matrix-matrix and matrixtranspose matrix multiplications, respectively. Hence, after computing the small sized ϕ-functions, formula (7) can be efficiently realized with two GEMM calls. Similarly, the generic d-dimensional formulation (6) can be implemented with d GEMM calls as floating point operations, see Reference [5] for more details. Clearly, formula (6) can not be directly employed in formulation (4), since it would lead to an order reduction of the resulting integrator. In the following subsections, we will then look for third order direction split approximations of ϕ-functions similar to formula (6), in the sense that their realization will require few Tucker operators (that we recall again constitute the major computational cost).

sections.heading: 3. Numerical results
sections.text:
In this section, we present an application of the proposed approximations for efficiently solving two popular physical models, namely the FitzHugh–Nagumo and the Schnakenberg systems, with exponential integrators. For both examples, we first perform a semidiscretization in space using second order uniform centered finite differences, with nµ = n discretization points per direction. Then, for the time marching we consider the third order exponential Runge–Kutta integrator in formula (4) with coefficients c2 = 1 3 , c3 = 2 3 , a32(·) = 23ϕ2(c3·), b2(·) = 0, and b3(·) = 32ϕ2(·) (labeled exprk3, see also tableau (5.8) in Reference [6]) in combination with the proposed technique for computing ϕ-functions. As splitting coefficients we always employ the ones corresponding to the choice of the symbol + in the expression of α1 or α1,µ. Moreover, to compute the needed small sized ϕ-functions we employ the function phiquad from Reference [2]. The resulting directional split exponential integrator is labeled exprk3ds cplx when employing splitting with complex coefficients, and exprk3ds real when using real ones.
As term of comparison we consider the second order directional split integrator proposed in Reference [3] (that we denote etd2rkds), which corresponds to the popular etd2rk scheme (i.e., tableau (5.3) in Reference [6] with c2 = 1) with second order directional splitting of the involved ϕ-functions. Moreover, we present also the results with the etd2rk and the exprk3 integrators (without directional splitting) where the actions of ϕ-functions are approximated with a popular and efficient Krylov-based technique [12].
All the numerical experiments have been performed on an Intel Core i7-5500U CPU with 12GB of RAM using MathWorks MATLAB® R2022a, and the code to reproduce the examples (fully compatible with GNU Octave) is publicly available in the GitHub repository https://github.com/cassinif/Expds3.

sections.heading: 3.1. Two-dimensional FitzHugh–Nagumo model
sections.text:
We consider system {
∂tu = δ u∆u+ ρ(−u(u2 − 1)− v), ∂tv = δ v∆v + ρav1(u− av2v),
(14)
in the spatial domain Ω = [0, π]2. This model is typically employed in the study of Turing patterns, see for instance References [3, 13]. The parameters are set to δu = 1, δv = 42.1887, ρ = 65.731, av1 = 11, and av2 = 0.1. The final simulation time is T = 10. We select as initial solution u0(x1, x2) = 10
−3 · U(0, 1) and v0(x1, x2) = 10
−3 · U(0, 1), being U(0, 1) a uniform random variable in (0, 1) with default MATLAB seed. The spatial domain is discretized by a grid of N = n2 = 1002 points, and we employ a number of time steps ranging from 60000 to 75000 for the second order integrators, while from 10000 to 17500 for the third order ones. The results are collected in Figure 1.
First of all, we observe that all the schemes show the expected order of convergence, with a magnitude of the error comparable among the second and third order methods, respectively. The advantage of the proposed technique is neat in terms of simulation wall-clock time. In fact, both the third order directional split integrators perform better than etd2rkds for the range of accuracies under study. Also, as expected the cheapest method among exprk3ds cplx and exprk3ds real is the latter, which overall is the scheme that performs best.
